Posts.Content: Hi Sue. I don't mind you asking at all. I'm on the south coast. My rationale for having this done was that I didn't want to spend the rest of my life being neurotic about my lumpy boobs. I want to be able to put this particular episode behind me and I don't feel I'll be able to do that until they're gone. They wanted to be sure I understood that having it done will not prevent cancer in any way, but for me it will stop me obsessing and worrying about whether the lumps I have are or have turned cancerous. If you need more specific details please PM me. I don't want to cause any dissension amongst the professionals! And let's remember it hasn't been done yet! I have to wait 6 months. However as I was leaving I did actually confirm their agreement to make sure they wouldn't go back on their word. Lets hope they keep it. I hope this explanation helps in some way x
Posts.Title: Thinking of voluntary MX

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca. I to have asked my surgeon to give me a double mastectomy as I can't bear to live my life wondering if the cancer will return. I have a history of very lumpy boobs and yet my breast cancer was discovered by a routine mammogram and there was no lump! I need to wait 6 months to give my body time to recover from chemo and rads first, but I can't wait to get rid of them! I know absolutely that this is the right decision for me, but we are all so different. Good luck with your decision x
Posts.Title: Thinking of voluntary MX

Posts.Content: Ready to eat figs or prunes are good. I put linseed (the seeds not the oil!) in my muesli too. Nothing worse than that awful "full" feeling.
Posts.Title: What to drink?

Posts.Content: Hi Annie. Please call your BCN - another day worrying is a day too long. Take a deep breath, pick up the phone and dial. I can't bear the thought of you feeling like this and feeling unable to do anything about it. Take the first step - you can do it! X
Posts.Title: really scared

Posts.Content: Hi. All Trusts should be following the regulations regarding patients access to their notes. The notes whilst about don't belong to you and so there will be a process to go through. Some medics are much better and more open about sharing info Contacting your Trusts PALS team would be a good way to get the ball rolling. Hope this helps and you're able to get to see the info you want. Take care x
Posts.Title: Patient Notes

Posts.Content: Hi Annabel. I'm sooo envious. I would love a dog, but I live in a flat and when not dealing with chemo work f/t. All you lucky dog owners out there-give them a hug for me please! Have a fab holiday!
Posts.Title: Bought a puppy :)

Posts.Content: Hi Annabel. I'm sooo envious. I would love a dog, but I live in a flat and when not dealing with chemo work f/t. All you lucky dog owners out there-give them a hug for me please! Have a fab holiday!
Posts.Title: Bought a puppy :)

Posts.Content: I have to do these injections for 10 days post chemo and I hate them - not least because of the wretched effect they have on my mouth and taste buds. I don't know why there seems to be such a variation on the number of them we have to take, but I wish I was at the lower end of the scale!
Posts.Title: Docetaxal for me better than FEC

Posts.Content: Mine was picked up by a routine mammogram. It was the tiniest speck imaginable and couldn't be felt or seen by ultrasound. Diagnosis was confirmed by biopsy. If you or your friend feel more should be done to confirm what it, my advice would be to shout and shout until you get what you feel you need. Good luck xxx
Posts.Title: Lump, dimpling to the skin but clear ultrasound-still worried

Posts.Content: Fab news. Onwards and upwards. X
Posts.Title: never thought would be so happy to have surgery!!

Posts.Content: Ha ha. My phone pinged and your post hit home! My journey started last Jan. routine mammogram which showed pre cancerous changes, then DCIS, then 1st surgery, 2nd surgery which showed cancer was HER2+. Had chemo and radio and back to work mid Dec! Yes it is a roller coaster. Yes it is hard. Yes it is scary. BUT you get through it and find yourself changed but mostly for the good! This site was a lifesaver. Not that I was very active, but the support you gain on here is amazing. Whatever you are going through, there will be someone to share with you. You take care x
Posts.Title: in two minds about mastectomy, but it's the surgeon I'm uneasy with

Posts.Content: Hi Nightingale. I work in Brighton but live in Worthing. I had my survey in Worthing. There are a number of surgeons there all of whom are very experienced. It's your right to choose where you have your surgery. I'm sure your breast care nurses can help you with resolving the problem you have with your current surgeon. Stick with what you need. You are the patient and need to feel comfortable with your treatment and who is giving it to you. You will get through it! X
Posts.Title: in two minds about mastectomy, but it's the surgeon I'm uneasy with

Posts.Content: You go girl. That's the inspiration that will help us get through this together. Congrats and thanks! xxx
Posts.Title: Chemo ends - Where's the wine and the tissues?!!!

Posts.Content: Was it me Dee? If so friend me and then we can exchange emails away from the forum x
Posts.Title: Worthing hospital!

Posts.Content: I too am through this trip on my own, and yes it really is hard. The hardest thing for me is getting the balance right. I either ignore feeling poorly until it causes a problem or I panic and think every single twinge is a death knell. How do others manage to find that middle way?
Posts.Title: Living alone

Posts.Content: Hi. I had this too and when I mentioned it to the chemo nurses they got the doc to prescribe some eye drops. Perhaps you should mention so you can get some relief. Take care. JP x
Posts.Title: Sore eyes

Posts.Content: Yew tree clippings and avocado? There isn't a salad dressing on earth that would perk that meal up!
Posts.Title: Docetaxol You B*****D !!!

Posts.Content: Me too Jellytot. Have been poorly since 1st Tax on Friday. Seems I've had a bad reaction and I'm now severely dehydrated. Thinking of you and hoping neither of us are in for long x
Posts.Title: Docetaxol You B*****D !!!

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey. Your post has really given me hope that come Friday when I'm due my 2nd docetaxol I won't be so ill as I was after my first as my onc has also reduced the dose by 20%. I was dreading having to go through that again and so I hope like you it isn't so bad. Take care xxx
Posts.Title: Docetaxol You B*****D !!!

Posts.Content: Hi Patricia. I chose to have a PICC line before my first FEC-T for all the good practical reasons you state. Sadly though after 10 days my arm ballooned, was very painful and turned blue and an ultrasound showed a clot so the line had to be removed and I am now on Fragmin for 6 weeks to dissolve it. Hopefully they are going to try me with a port in a couple of weeks to save my veins. I'm sure your line will be fine but just wanted to give a balanced view so you can make a fully informed choice. I hope I haven't caused you any upset though by replying with my experience. Good luck. I hope it goes well x
Posts.Title: New with PICC line

Posts.Content: Hi. Speaking as someone who was in exact situation As you are this time last week and ended up being admitted the best advice I can give is take the pain relief but also monitor your fluid intake and ensure you keep that up too. My gut lining was severely affected by the docetaxol and in the end I was losing more than I was putting in and then started to pass out every time I tried to stand and fell and injured myself.. If you're worried DO NOT hesitate to call your unit today before they close so they can reassure you. The nights are very very long when you're in pain and feeling out of control. I so hope you don't get to where I am and that you find relief quickly. Take very good care of yourself xxx
Posts.Title: HOW LONG!

Posts.Content: I'm due my 3rd FEC next Weds and my nails have started to turn black. Goodness knows what I'm in for when I start docetaxol. So much to look forward to!!!!
Posts.Title: Black nail varnish & Docetaxel
